content.text: Define density
Determine the density of the glass
density =   .........  kg m⁻³
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density
percentage uncertainty =   .........  %
Fig. 1.1 shows a cuboidal glass block
A student measures the mass \(m\) of the block and the side lengths \(x\), \(y\) and \(z\). The measurements are shown in Table 1.1
The true value of the density of the glass is different from the answer in **(b)**(i) because of a systematic error in the measurements
Suggest **one** possible cause of this systematic error
Define linear momentum
Calculate the maximum speed reached by the car
maximum speed =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-1}\)
Calculate the maximum kinetic energy of the car
maximum kinetic energy =   .........  J
Show that the acceleration of the car at time \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\) is \(5.0 \text{m s}^{-2}\)
Determine the distance travelled by the car between times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 12.0 \text{s}\)
distance =   .........  m
A car of mass \(1800\mathrm{kg}\) is moving in a straight line. Fig. 2.1 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the momentum \(p\) of the car
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the acceleration \(a\) of the car in **(b)** from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 12.0 \text{s}\)
State what is meant by the work done by a force
A block of mass \(m\) is raised vertically at constant speed. The vertical height gained by the block is \(\Delta h\), as shown in Fig. 3.1
Derive an expression, in terms of \(m\) and \(\Delta h\), for the change in gravitational potential energy \(\Delta E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the block. State the meaning of any other symbols you use
Show that the work done by the motor on the load in 1.0 minute is \(36\mathrm{kJ}\)
Determine the useful output power of the motor
Use your answer in (c)(ii) to determine the efficiency of the motor
efficiency =   .........
Some of the power wasted in the motor is dissipated by the resistance of its coil. This dissipated power is 280W

The coil of the motor is made from wire of total length \(23\mathrm{m}\). The wire has a cross-sectional area of \(2.6 \times 10^{- 8}\mathrm{m}^2\) and is made from metal of resistivity \(1.7 \times 10^{- 8}\Omega \mathrm{m}\)
Calculate the current in the coil
current =   .........  A

An electric motor has an input power of \(900\mathrm{W}.\) The motor takes 1.0 minute to lift a load of weight \(240\mathrm{N}\) at constant speed through a vertical height of \(150\mathrm{m}\). Resistive forces are negligible
Define the Young modulus of a material
On Fig. 4.1, sketch the variation of tensile force \(F\) in the wire with its extension \(x\)
State the name of the quantity represented by the gradient of the line in Fig. 4.1
State the name of the quantity represented by the area under the line in Fig. 4.1
A metal wire P that obeys Hooke's law is stretched within its limit of proportionality
Another wire Q is made from a metal that has twice the Young modulus of the metal of wire P in (b). Wire Q has the same volume as wire P but has double the cross-sectional area of wire P
The two wires are extended by equal tensile forces within their limits of proportionality
State and explain how the extension of wire Q compares with the extension of wire P
State the values of \(P\), \(Q\), \(R\) and \(S\)
State the name of particle Z
State the name of the class of fundamental particle to which both the \(\beta^{- }\) particle and particle Z belong
Potassium-40 ( \(^{40}_{19}\mathrm{K})\) undergoes \(\beta^{- }\) decay to form a nuclide of element X. Particle Z is emitted during the decay. The equation for the decay is shown
Determine the quark composition of an alpha-particle
quark composition   .........
Explain why the position of greatest intensity is not at point O
On Fig. 6.1, draw a cross \((\times)\) to show the position of the point on line PQ where the intensity minimum that is the closest to point O occurs. Label this point B
Show that the wavelength of the microwaves is \(0.012 \text{m}\)
For point A on line PQ, determine the difference in the distances \(\Delta x\) travelled by the microwaves from X and the microwaves from Y
Use the formula for the double-slit interference of light to calculate the distance between adjacent intensity maxima on line PQ
distance =   .........  m
Two coherent sources X and Y of microwaves of frequency \(2.5 \times 10^{10} \text{Hz}\) are a distance of \(0.18 \text{m}\) apart in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 6.1
(not to scale)
There is a phase difference of \(90^{\circ}\) between the waves emitted at the two sources
A microwave detector moves along the line PQ, which is parallel to the line joining the two sources and \(2.3 \text{m}\) away from it
Point O is on the line PQ at a position that is equidistant from the two sources
Point A is the position on line PQ where the intensity of the microwaves is the greatest
Show that the current \(I\) in the circuit is \(0.50 \text{A}\)
Calculate the combined resistance of the two resistors
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
Use your answer in (a)(ii) to determine resistance \(R\)
Fig. 7.1 shows two resistors connected in series with a cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(1.50 \text{V}\) and internal resistance \(0.28 \Omega\)
One of the resistors has resistance \(1.0 \Omega\). The other resistor has resistance \(R\)
The terminal potential difference (p.d.) across the cell is \(1.36 \text{V}\)
On Fig. 7.2, complete the circuit diagram to show this arrangement
Explain, without calculation, whether the terminal p.d. across the cell is now less than, equal to or greater than 1.36V
The circuit in Fig. 7.1 is disconnected and the two resistors are reconnected to the cell, now in parallel with each other
